heisig_chinese_memo: A pelt covering is hooked on a branch. A small tent is made with a pelt covering and a branch planted in the ground. The mnemonic hints at the first stroke (the hanging pelt) and the hook at the end of the second stroke. This is chinese radical #107 meaning ‚Äúskin‚Äù.
heisig_constituent: pelt, branch, ten, needle, crotch, hook
heisig_story: The simplest way to remember this character is to see it as built up from that for branch. The first stroke can then stand for something "hanging" down from the branch, namely its bark or pelt. The barb at the end of the second stroke is the only other change. Merely by concentrating on this as you write the following small cluster of characters should be enough to fix the form in your mind. By way of exception, you might doodle around with the kanji's form to see what you can come up with.

WaniKani_Meaning_Mnemonic: Slide down a branch and your skin will come off. Unlike what Tarzan will make you believe, you can't just slide around on branches, they're rough and painful and if you do it your skin will come sliding off and it will hurt.
WaniKani_Meaning_Info: Imagine sliding down a slide made of a big, branch. The branch's bark digs into your skin and pulls it right off of your body.
WaniKani_Reading_Mnemonic: Without your skin to protect you, you feel the full heat („Å≤) from the friction of your body going down the branch slide.
WaniKani_Reading_Info: Your skin protects you from really feeling lots of heat. It gets burned before you and it has many tiny layers to keep you safe from heat generating things like the sun. You really need your skin!

humanum_full_description_en:
Oracle " again " is at the top, inscription " again " is at the bottom. The shape of the beast's mouth was later corrupted to " twenty ", and then to " bamboo " (Ji Xusheng), which was taken from the ancient prose of "Shuowen". Said a " skin " from the word " and " from " leather " province, like the hand-shaped strip of leather beast (Wang Guowei). The original meaning is skinning, animal skins, "Shuowen": "Skin, the one who strips the animal leather is called the skin. Congyou is the province of sound. All the skins are from the skin. •¨ñ(§ø§), ancient text skin. †∞é( §øå), Á±íÊñáÁöÆ." Xu Kai's "Shuowen Jiezi Biography": "Sheng is called skin, reason is called leather, and soft is called Wei."

The oracle bone inscriptions are incomplete and the meaning is unknown. Bronze inscriptions are used as rewards to represent animal skins. Nine-year guard: "Xipi II", which represents two ramskins. It is also known as " bi ", a demonstrative pronoun, referring to that, Zhongshan Wang Yuanhu: "Yupi (bi) XinÊù¢", "XinÊù¢" is a place name. Also used as a surname and personal name.

The bamboo slips of the Warring States Period were used as the original meaning, "Sleeping Tiger Land Qin Slips. Eighteen Kinds of Laws of the Qin Dynasty, Jian 7: "Eat its flesh and get into the skin", which means eating its flesh and turning in its skin.

"Sleeping Tiger Land Qin Bamboo Slips. "Xiao Lv" Jan 42: "Leather", "Zuo Zhuan. "The Five Years of the Hidden Master": "Leather teeth, bone corners and hairiness." Kong Yingdashu: "Hairy for skin, hairless for leather."

It is also known as " broken ", "Guodian Bamboo Slips. "Yu Cong IV": "Pie (Broken) a dead general" means that the country is destroyed and the generals die (Chen Wei).

Bamboo slips and silk scripts in the Han Dynasty were called " bi ", referring to that, "Mawangdui silk script. The 5th line of Laozi Jiaben: "So peel off the skin (that) to take this." "Yinqueshan Hanjian. The Art of War. Conspiracy: "The old soldier knows his skin (he) and his confidant".

Also known as " being ", "Mawangdui. Yin and Yang Eleven Meridian Moxibustion Classics, Line 66: "Skin (quilt) hair", which means hair loss. " Bei " is also called " pi ", "Mawangdui Silk Book. Ten Questions" Jian 20: "The (leather) leather has light." "Mawangdui. "He Yin Yang" Jian 128: "Skin Qi and Blood".

See also " gram ".

(1) Animal skins. Wearing fur is called leather, and removing fur is called leather.
(2) By extension, it refers to a layer of tissue on the surface of human skin or animal and plant bodies.
(3) Fur; leather.
(4) Refers to Pihou. A shooting target made of animal skins in ancient times.
(5) Peel off the skin.
(6) The surface of the object.
(7) The extension is superficial and superficial. See "Pixiang", "Pifu".
(8) A bag or a layer of things surrounding an object.
(9) Refers to some thin-shaped things.
(10) Dialects. Not brittle, but tough.
(11) Dialects. Naughty
(12) Shameless; nonchalant.
(13) Refers to rubber or rubber.
(14) Through "bi".
(15) Last name. There was Pi Rixiu in the Tang Dynasty.

Radicals: ‰∏ø, ÊîØ  (slide, branch)
Meaning Mnemonic
Slide down a branch and your skin will come off. Unlike what Tarzan will make you believe, you can't just slide around on branches, they're rough and painful and if you do it your skin will come sliding off and it will hurt.
Imagine sliding down a slide made of a big, branch. The branch's bark digs into your skin and pulls it right off of your body.
Reading Mnemonic
Without your skin to protect you, you feel the full heat („Å≤) from the friction of your body going down the branch slide.
Your skin protects you from really feeling lots of heat. It gets burned before you and it has many tiny layers to keep you safe from heat generating things like the sun. You really need your skin!
